Skate is an absolute masterpiece for those who adore skating in a very realistic and also creative way. The main thing that makes Skate so good is the fact that it captures the very essence of real skateboarding perfectly. not only the tricks but also the flow, timing, and style. Skate, unlike other skating games that have players mashing buttons to perform combos. Skaters would do it just the same way if they had the chance. The open world design lets players draw their paths through a great big city filled with exploring, discovering hidden spots, and making their own lines. Every action, such as grind and flip, even bail, has become more realistic and exciting through the undemanding yet great physics of the game, and the players never get tired of that for the reason that it is so naturally exciting. Besides it all, there is room for creativity, making your own movie clips, altering your skater, and communicating your mood by means of tricks and combos. Skate is also a community builder by making it possible for players to play against their mates, to exchange footage, and to demonstrate their talent online. Each session reminds of a gathering at the park with friends where everyone is trying out different things, and testing limits. It‚Äôs not just a skating game, it‚Äôs a way of life.. a way to keep the culture alive, to honor the struggle, and to celebrate the freedom that skating brings.

The physics are great and the slams are actually kind of realistic. The map can feel repetitive at times, but if you look harder (and slow down) you'll start finding more and more hidden spots. The challenges are also repetitive but some of them are really creative and push me out of my comfort zone. The game is free, so that's nice but...

There is zero skateboard culture in this game. It's soulless and dead in a way that is very disappointing. On one hand, I'm happy they focused on making the mechanics fun but it's basically a big sandbox with loot boxes. Eventually, after you've done every challenge, the game will be nothing but a big free roam map that you've already skated for dozens of hours. No getting footy for a part, no demos for sponsors, no actual pro skaters, and very few real skateboard brands. The loot boxes are really annoying. Not only is most of the content generic AI generated slop (oh great I unlocked a pepperoni pizza sticker!), actually unlocking it is a tedious loop of silly "Congratulations" transitions that make you want to pull your hair out. The art direction is too cartoony and the skate customization is lacking. My skater looks like a wax doll. Progression in the districts is confusing. I think it's tied to the loot boxes? I don't even know or really care to be honest. Almost all the other skaters you encounter in the world are wearing the same exact outfit because the stuff you get in the loot boxes is so corny. 

This is a fun skateboarding sandbox but it is also a testament to how corporate and devoid of culture games like this are becoming. It's really ironic that a genre of games led originally by the THPS and THUG series that were full of amazing skateboarding culture, footage, brands, and references has ended up like this. And we know the Skate games that preceded this were inspired by those games and full of skateboarding culture. I'm very torn because I love the actual skating in this game, but it's not really a video game. It's more like a really good proof of concept. If it wasn't free I would not recommend spending money on it.

However, these concerns are actively being addressed, and you can really see the direction improving over time.

Developer Communication
One of the most encouraging aspects is the team‚Äôs transparency and communication. They‚Äôve been open about changes, receptive to feedback, and genuinely seem committed to shaping Skate into something great.

I think that this game provides just enough shielding from the bad to be considered a positive review.

Pros: 
-Tricks: they feel rewarding and at least somewhat consistent. HItting a sick line really gives a nice dopamine hit when you finally nail something you have been trying to hit.
-Free to play: this is such a big factor as there is no game like this that offers a free to play + not p2w system and that has to be admired + praised
-Community: seeing others skate around and being able to interact and see what others are up to really adds a fun level of immersion + community
-adding props to the world for people to add and build there own lines on the fly is a brilliant feature
-Customization: I believe this still to be in its infancy and I was torn to put this in pro or con. A lot of clothing you get will just feel like reskinned items. Eg: you will get 4 jeans maybe all with a slight color/material difference - however they use the same models. I don't mind reusing models with new skins, but then the price needs to be adjusted accordingly. No one should shell out 4$+ for an item that is just a reskinned same model as they own.
-Climbing: while janky at times offers a fun way to get around to high+new places

Cons:
I am going to start with the biggest most glaring issue to me.
STOP CONGRATULATING ME FOR EVERY ITEM AND EVERY TASK.

-holy mother of god. 80 hours played sure. I however have spend maybe 20 hours just skipping through CONGRATLUATIONS YOUVE UNLOCKED "X" followed by me skipping. Then proceeding to get the same congratulations message over and over again through some disgusting glitched loop that just abuses your time. Please for the love of god make a way to turn off these reward messages. Just add them to my inventory or something ill find it later. ANYTHING but the the current system.

-The AI + "story": the last thing I want when I am skating around is some A.I voice barking in my head. It is one the most out of touch things i have ever seen in any video game. Yet alone a skateboarding video game. Anyone who tries this game. Know, that you can turn it off in settings and I reccomend doing that, Unless you wish to be harrassed by an AI voice that screams out of touch lingo at you every time you fail or succeed anything.
The "story" if you want to even call it that has you doing missions that more or less just teach you the ins and outs of skating and the moves you will encounter. The only issue wtih this is that a lot of these missions are locked behind completeing "x" amount of challenges. So you will often go do all these challenges just to do a mission. Then ironically you will be taught something that you already had done in previous challenges to even get to the point of doing the mission. Therefore making the whole mission pointless since you already learned and used the thing they are trying to actively teach you. I think the skate. team made a critical error when thinking this through. All the missions should be at the start of the game. So that way you learn all the moves needed for the challenges. Not the other way around.

-invisible barriers + smooth transitions: I find myself running into invisible artifacts while grinding way too much. EG: you'll be grinding a long a smooth flat surface and out of nowhere your character will either just go flying or just completely bail. Some spots I have noticed have invisible "humps" where if you ride over the area too fast you fall. What I mean by smooth transitions is there is just a lot of not well thought out placement of different props or items by developers. EG: you will have a beautiful area to grind but randomly they just put some crap in the middle that then ruins what could have been a really cool line. I get that things are there to add environment+scenery but just thought for a skating game it could do a bit better in that area.

-Cosmetic Prices: This is pretty self explanitory. I would say that the price of the "premium" cash you buy is about 3x more expensive than it should be.  Barring me from ever actually supporting the game with currency. Since that is just a complete rip off. The lowest amount you can buy is 7$ where I live and that gets you maybe 2-3 cosmetics(low tier) or 1 (high tier). There is basically no way beyond the season pass to earn the premium currency. And the season pass gives you chump change. Even if you complete the entire season you wont be able to get season pass with the currency earned. You would still need to buy it or wait an entire other season while saving the entire time. MAKE WAYS TO EARN IT. I shouldn't feel "broke" after 80 hours of grinding it out but there is no chance I will ever earn enough to get premium. 
Season Pass: Feels majorly unbalanced towards the premium aspect. EG: all the coolest unlocks are premium(go figure) but along with that almost every step of the season pass has about 4 free items then about 6-7 premium items. The part that is most criminal about all of this? LOCKING THE LAST UNLOCK OF THE SEASON TO BE PREMIUM ONLY. Thats right. You heard that correct. You grinded all the way to end of the season? Feel like you should be rewarded for all the grinding you did? Well pay me money to be rewarded. Because the last items on the season pass page that are in the Free category is just a bunch of garbage that you would expect to just get out of one of the WAAAY to many:

-Loot boxes these game companies that just unnecessarily add loot boxes to everything is just insane to me. This game really drives that home. It is so uneeded and adds nothing of value besides creating future gambling addicts. Which I would assume is EA's goal here. You easily could have just made it so you unlocked each of the things in these "lootboxes" via completing challenges or rewards themselves, but you just couldnt help yourselves.....



-Challenges: I find that all the challenges are 1 of 2 things. They are either 1. the easiest thing you have ever done, requiring pretty much minimal effort. 2. You are fighting the jank of the game and its set on extreme. I find so many challenges will have you doing all these precise movements and landings but the game just doesn't set you up for it properly. EG: you will be assigned to go off a ramp and land a trick but the ramp wont line up with anything so you go off the ramp and have no where to land properly. You will see arrows to guide you on these ramps but the arrows are decorations at times because if you follow the arrows you will fail the mission from falling off the area. This is one example of something like this but I can probably think of like 3-5 challenges I've done where it was me just wanting to rip my eyeballs out, fighting the jank of the game, only to not really even feel accomplished when I complete it. 

What challenges should be: Actual combinations of tricks or precise lines. This would feel WAY more satifying then me hitting some ramp just right. It would improve on your skill too.  You guys are already almost there, just make them more challenging. You guys should be ok with not everyone being able to complete every challenge. I would love to have something that pushes my skill. Because at the moment it's only myself through my own satisfaction that is progressin me.





TL;DR : Early access , Fun, free, overpriced cosmetics + season pass, janky in ways, could use some improvements overall, time invested + challenges isn't as rewarding as it could be.

That's why this game brands itself as "early-access"
However, if you sell in-game currency for up to 100‚Ç¨, Have a fully functioning seasonal system with battlepasses and 20‚Ç¨ cosmetic bundles, then you're not in early access. This is a fully released game, disguised as an early-access title in order to avoid any criticism.

When it comes to visuals, they are extremely lackluster and lack STYLE. 
Usually I don't comment on visuals in a game, but with a skating game and Skate games in particular, you expect a certain tone and art-style. It's extremely cartoony and unlike Fortnite, the customization leaves a lot to be desired. You cannot change the color of your clothes, you cannot change the position of your cap, there are no tattoos, you cannot color your hair with custom colors, there's next to no body shapes and I could go on. It's quite the paradox actually, because despite the game pushing so hard for cosmetics, there's not only a very narrow selection of them, but the quality LACKS. There's very few Boards, Grip colors, Grip patterns, Hoodies, T-shirts and so on. Cosmetics in the shop are extremely overpriced and rarely look good. On the topic of branded clothing and other customization related to real-life brands, why are there no real-life personalities? Where are all the pro-skaters? People who paid for cosmetics? your money is forever gone! Oh, you wanna play the game? tough luck buddy! it's an online-only game! This feels like the antithesis of what the skate games used to be. There's no grit, no skate culture and everything feels so manufactured and corporatized. It's as if any part of this game I might have liked while it was going through development was hit with 10 different grits of sandpaper to knock off any edges someone could possibly find offensive or not happy/uplifting enough to fit in a corporate boardroom.

If you grew up loving skate 1, skate 2 and skate 3 you probably won't love whatever this is supposed to be, because it certainly isn't skate.
It feels so much more like a hollow shell to fill with microtransactions than it does a sequel to a beloved franchise. 

The physics seem decent and the controls feel more or less like they used to, but Skate 2 and 3 already had fine physics and controls. I much prefer those games in graphical style, art direction and connection to skateboarding over this and I don't get loot boxes shoved down my throat for completing missions on those.

I'd recommend Session or Skater XL instead or go replay the older games in the franchise if it's been a while since you've done so.
